I was shopping at my local supermarket
as I normally have for years.
One particular day, I had done about 2 weeks’ worth of shopping
and was headed toward the register to pay for my groceries.
I reached into my back right pocket
to grab the money to pay
and noticed that there was no money in there.
I started to get nervous.
I knew my pocket book was in the car
and I was sure I had put the money in my back right pocket.
I look at cashier with a confused look,
not knowing what to do.
There were people behind me on the line
and I immediately thought about the money I left in the car
that was intended to pay rent this month.
She told me to speak with the courtesy counter.
I laughed and said,
"But it was cash, no one would hand that in!"
I decided that there was no harm in checking
so I walked up to a woman behind the counter
and said "I have to ask, did anyone turn in cash by any chance?"
She asked "How much?"
My face then lit up.
in the form of twenty dollar bills." I replied.
She said, "Actually, yes, someone did!"
I was so surprised!
"Who? I want to thank them."
She points to a young girl
about 10 years old
and says, "She did."
I walked over to the mom
and hugged her.
She said, "It wasn't me, it was my daughter".
I was so happy,
I was almost in tears.
I decided in those moments to do my duty
to pay forward this act of kindness
every opportunity I had.
Larry Walters had a dream that he could fly.
The problem was that Larry's vision was poor,
recText: Unfortunately, his vision was not that good

origText: and he was thus ill-suited to become a pilot.

origText: On a sunny summer day
in his modest backyard
in San Pedro,
Larry boarded a makeshift aircraft
comprising a lawn chair,
recText: a lawn chair

origText: a seat belt,
and forty-odd weather balloons.
recText: some weather balloon

origText: Armed with a pellet gun,
recText: a pellet gun

origText: a CB radio,
recText: CW radio

origText: and a cooler full of sandwiches,
he released the line that tethered his craft
to his Jeep,
rose to a height of thirty feet or so,
and had himself a little picnic.
He planned to just shoot out a couple balloons and float gently back to earth,
recText: He was going to float around and then shoot out the weather balloons to come back to the ground

origText: just as easy as could be.
But Larry, it would seem, was not so good with physics.
recText: unfortunately, Larry was not good at physics

origText: When he released the tether, his craft rose
15,000 feet in the air.
According to some reports,
he didn't dare shoot out the balloons,
recText: Scared that shooting a balloon out

origText: for fear the chair would tip.
recText: would cause the chair to tip

origText: Eventually, he drifted into the approach corridor of Long Beach airport,
disrupting air traffic.
Imagine for a moment what that must have looked like to the folks waiting for clearance to land:
a man in a lawn chair with a gun,
some three miles above the ground.
He did finally touch down safely,
recText: He finally landed on the ground

origText: though not before getting tangled in some power lines
and knocking out power in the entire Long Beach area.
It goes without saying that Larry, upon touchdown, was arrested.
Seems the FAA took umbrage with his violation of restricted airspace.
But by the time they nabbed him, the story had spread,
and a few crack reporters witnessed his arrest.
One of those reporters asked why he'd done it.
Larry's response?
"A man can't just sit around."

origText: Mr. Johnston laughs.

Susie ignores me.

“She’s here every day,” says Mr. Johnston
before walking back inside the store.
I wait until Susie finishes her fish head,
and we walk home together.

“Hi Ryan,” he calls in his thick Brooklyn accent.
“So this is where Susie comes at noon,” I say, walking towards him.
Mr. Johnston laughs.
“Yep.  All the cats come to visit me at noon.
They used to tear up my garbage,
so now I just put the fish heads on the ground for them.
Is that your cat?”
Susie ignores me.
The fish head is more interesting at the moment.
“Yes, that’s my Susie,” I say.
“She’s here every day,” says Mr. Johnston
before walking back inside the store.
I wait until Susie finishes her fish head,
and we walk home together.
